questiontext.text:
Find the characteristic polynomial of {@M1@}.

Note: Use the variable "lambda" as the unknown term in the characteristic polynomial.

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Find the nth term of the following sequence: 

{@q(1)@}, {@q(2)@}, {@q(3)@}, {@q(4)@}, {@q(5)@}, ... 

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Let \( x_n\) be defined as follows: \(x_n = {@q(n)@} \), where \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).

In order to show \(x_n\) is a divergent sequence, we can show that two subsequences of \(x_n\) converge to two distinct limits:

\( \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_m \rm \) = [[input:ans1]], where \( m \) = [[input:ans2]] .

[[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]]

\( \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_k \rm \) = [[input:ans3]], where \( k \) = [[input:ans4]] .

[[validation:ans3]] [[validation:ans4]]

Find the characteristic polynomial of {@M2@}.

Note: Use the variable "lambda" as the unknown term in the characteristic polynomial.

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Let \(x_n = {@x(n)@}\), where \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). 

List the first 5 terms of \(x_n\). 

\(x_1\) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] 

\(x_2\) = [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] 

\(x_3\) = [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] 

\(x_4\) = [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] 

\(x_5\) = [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

In case of convergence, determine \(\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n \rm \).

[[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

Let \(x_n = {@q@} \), where \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). 

Determine the monotonicity, boundedness and convergence of \(x_n\).

[[input:ans1]] [[input:ans2]] [[input:ans3]]

[[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]]  [[validation:ans3]]

Using the characteristic polynomial from Problem 1, find the eigenvalues of {@M1@}.

For creating a set of multiple eigenvalues, use the syntax {lambda = ..., lambda = ....}.

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Let \(x_n = {@x(n)@}\), where \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). 

Determine the limit \(a\) of \(x_n\), where \(\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n \rm = a \)

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Find a number \(N\) for \(ε = 10^{@q@}\) , such that for all \(n > N\) the relation \(|x_n − a| < ε\) is satisfied.

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

Using the characteristic polynomial from Problem 2, find the eigenvalues of {@M2@}.

For creating a set of multiple eigenvalues, use the syntax {lambda = ..., lambda = ...., lambda = ...}.

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Based on its eigenvalues, determine the definiteness of {@M1@}.

[[input:ans1]] 

[[validation:ans1]]

Based on its eigenvalues, determine the definiteness of {@M1@}.

[[input:ans1]] 

[[validation:ans1]]

The sequences \(a_n\) and \(b_n\) behave in such a way that \(\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} ({@lhs(q[1])@}) = {@rhs(q[1])@} \rm \) and \(\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} ({@lhs(q[2])@}) = {@rhs(q[2])@} \rm \).

Determine: 

\(\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \rm \) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

\(\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} b_n \rm \) = [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]
